translated: When the invariable concomitance of the property of being an effect with the antecedence by an agent qualified by such and such a property is grasped through the apprehension of positive and negative concomitance,

translated: Because the state of being the ruler of the object of control, of that which is absolutely unconnected, is impossible, like the state of being the cutter of that which is unconnected with the axe, the object of control must be connected with the controller.

analyzed: bhavitavyam iti eva niyamaḥ

analyzed: tat vadati yatas iti
translated: He says that in 'yat' (because).

analyzed: adhiṣṭhīyamānam pravartyamānam

analyzed: sva saṃbandhinā a prerya saṃyoginā

analyzed: hasta ādi viśeṣyam atra

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ śarīriṇaḥ eva pravartaka tvam iti na niyamaḥ
translated: The idea is this: It is not a rule that only the embodied one is the instigator.

analyzed: hasta ādeḥ api māna daṇḍa ādi pravartaka tvāt
translated: Because the hand etc. is also the instigator of the measuring rod etc.

analyzed: prerya saṃbandhinaḥ eva preraka tvam iti saṃbhavati
translated: The state of being the instigator is possible only for that which is connected with the controlled.

analyzed: hasta ādeḥ api prerya sambandhāt iti
translated: Even of the hand etc., because of the connection with the impelled.

analyzed: śaṅkate atha i ti
translated: He doubts with 'But if' etc.
Impulsion means having an effort that causes another's activity.

analyzed: tat ca puruṣasya eva
translated: And that belongs to the person alone.

analyzed: sa ca sva hasta vyāpāreṇa māna daṇḍa ādi pravartayati
translated: And he impels the measuring rod etc. by the activity of his own hand.

original: tathā ca dehatadavayavabhinnavastupravartane dehahastādivyāpārāpekṣāsyeveti neśvarasyānākṛteḥ paramāṇvādyadhiṣṭhātṛtvaṃ saṃbhavatītyāśayaḥ

translated: And thus, in the impulsion of a thing different from the body and its parts, he alone depends on the activity of the body, hand etc. Therefore, the lordship of God, who is formless, over atoms etc. is not possible - this is the idea.

analyzed: imam api niyamam anaikāntyena eva dūṣayati tat api na iti
translated: He refutes this rule also with non-uniqueness, with 'That also is not' etc.

analyzed: saṅkalpagaruḍadhyāna ādi mānasa vyāpāra mātreṇa hasta ādi vyāpāram vinā api para śarīra stha viṣa nivartana ādi darśanāt deha tad avayava vyatirikta adhiṣṭhāne deha ādi vyāpāra apekṣā niyamaḥ
translated: Because of the cessation of poison etc. in another's body even without the activity of the hand etc. merely by the mental activity of will, contemplation of Garuda etc., there is no rule that in the impulsion of a thing different from the body and its parts, he depends on the activity of the body etc.

analyzed: na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: preryasaṃbandho 'pyatra prerakasya jñānadvāraka eveti ca bodhyam /
analyzed: prerya saṃbandhaḥ u pi atra prerakasya jñāna dvārakaḥ eva iti ca bodhyam
translated: And it should be understood that here the connection with the impelled is only through the knowledge of the impeller.

analyzed: punar śaṅkate
translated: Again he doubts

analyzed: katham iti janya jñāna ādau dehasya hetu tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: with 'How' etc. The idea is that because the body is the cause in the case of the knowledge that is to be produced etc.

analyzed: antar nihita uttaraḥ ākṣipati ki miti
translated: He raises the question with the answer implied in it: What?.

analyzed: dehasya kim saṅkalpe kartṛ tvam

original: yena yena tadabhāve saṅkalpo na ghaṭetetyarthaḥ /

translated: The meaning is: by which the will does not take place in the absence of that.

analyzed: śaṅkate karaṇam iti
translated: He raises the doubt: The instrument.

analyzed: tatra karaṇam śarīram iti ced na
translated: If the body is the instrument there, it is not so.

analyzed: manasaḥ eva karaṇa tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because the mind alone is the instrument.

original: tathā ca śarīrābhāve 'pi svahetoreva saṅkalpo bhaviṣyatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca śarīra abhāve pi sva hetoḥ eva saṅkalpaḥ bhaviṣyati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, even in the absence of the body, the will will take place from its own cause. This is the idea.

original: nanu manasaḥ karaṇatve 'pi janyajñānādau dehasyāpyastyevāpekṣāvacchedakatayeti cedatra brūmaḥbaddhajñānādāveva dehāpekṣā / nānyatra /

translated: If it is argued that even when the mind is the instrument, the body also has a role to play in the production of knowledge etc. by being the limiting adjunct, then we say in reply: The dependence on the body is only in the case of bound knowledge etc., not elsewhere.

original: 'manasaivaitān kāmān paśyan ramateya ete brahmaloke' 'manasaiva jagatsṛṣṭi'mityādinā muktasyeśvarasya ca manovattvaṃ /
analyzed: manasā eva etān kāmān paśyan ramate iye ete brahma loke manasā eva jagat sṛṣṭim ityādinā muktasya īśvarasya ca manaḥ vat tvam
translated: By the statements: Seeing these desires with the mind alone, he delights. These are in the world of Brahman, The creation of the world is by the mind alone, etc., the mind of the liberated one and of God is understood.

analyzed: tatas eva jñāna saṅkalpa ādikam ca pratīyate
translated: From that alone, knowledge, will, etc. are also understood.

analyzed: tad deha vigame pi manasaḥ nitya indriya tva upagamāt eva śarīra anapekṣa saṅkalpa ādi upapattiḥ iti
translated: Even on the separation from that body, the mind is accepted as a permanent sense organ, and the possibility of will, etc. without the body is established.

translated: But according to the logicians who maintain that God has eternal knowledge, will, and effort, there is even less dependence on a body, etc.

translated: Here, the support of having a mind and adventitious intention, etc. should be understood either according to the opinion of one of his followers or in the light of the established view.

analyzed: manovat tve niṣṭa prasaṅgam śaṅkate nanu evam iti
translated: He raises the objection that if God has a mind, undesirable consequences follow, with But it is not so.

analyzed: manovat tvasya śarīri tva ādi vyāpya tayā śarīri tva ādi āpadyeta īśvarasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because having a mind is pervaded by having a body, etc., God would be subject to having a body, etc.

analyzed: pariharati mā evam iti
translated: He replies, Not so,

original: samarthakartṛpūrvakatvena kāryatvasya vyāptergṛhītatvāt tataḥ kṣityādau sidhyataḥ karturīśvarasyāśarīritvaiśvaryādyeva setsyati 'yakṣānurūpo 🔽bali' riti nyāyāt /
analyzed: samartha kartṛ pūrvakatvena kāryatvasya vyāpteḥ gṛhīta tvāt tatas kṣiti ādau sidhyataḥ kartuḥ īśvarasya aśarīri tva aiśvarya ādi eva setsyati yakṣa anurūpaḥ  baliḥ iti nyāyāt
translated: because the pervasion of being an effect by being preceded by a capable agent has been grasped, from that the existence of God as the agent of earth, etc. will be established, and only his being bodiless, omniscience, etc. will be proved, according to the principle the offering is equal to the yaksha.

analyzed: śarīri tva ādi upagame ca asāmarthya prasaṅgāt
translated: And if having a body, etc. were accepted, incapacity would follow.

analyzed: yathā ca etat tathā na ca asmad ādeḥ iti anantara vākye vakṣyate

analyzed: tathā ca īśvare śarīra tva anaiśvarya ādi āpādanam dharmi grāhaka māna bādhitam iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus the consequence of God having a body, being not all-powerful, etc. is contradicted by the valid means of knowledge that grasps the subject, this is the meaning.

analyzed: draḍhimnā eva dṛḍha tayā eva
translated: By firmness, i.e. by strength.

analyzed: samartha kartṛka tva artha draḍhimnā eva iti samasta pāṭhaḥ sādhīyān
translated: The reading 'by the strength of the meaning of being done by a competent agent' is better.

analyzed: manasaḥ śarīri tva ādi vyāpya tvam api nirākaroti manasaḥ iti
translated: He also refutes the pervasion of the mind by corporeality, etc. with 'of the mind'.

original: sarīrābhāve 'pi prāyaṇāvāntaralayādau nityendriyatayā manasaḥ sattvātkālāvacchedena śarīravyāpyatvaṃ manaso nāstītyarthaḥ /🔽nanvevamapi saśarīrasyaiva kartṛtvaṃ tatra tatra dṛṣṭāmiti

translated: The meaning is that even in the absence of the body, during the intermediate dissolution at death, etc., the mind exists by being a permanent sense faculty, so the mind is not pervaded by the body in terms of time.

translated: Even so, how is it that the pervasion of being an effect by being done by one with a body is not grasped there, since agency is seen only of one with a body?🔽To this he says 'as long as there is cognition'.

original: dṛṣṭānuguṇaṃ kāryānugumatvena dṛṣṭamata eva vyāptyupayogi thadrūpaṃ tadavacchinnenaiva vyāptireṣṭavyā /

translated: The form that is useful for pervasion is to be accepted as pervaded only by what is delimited by that, since it is seen as being in conformity with the effect in accordance with what is seen.

analyzed: jñāna śaktyoḥ eva ca kārya anuguma tā

translated: Although they are dependent on the body in a potter, etc. who are subservient to karma,

translated: By 'being in conjunction with a pervasive substance', non-pervasiveness of the mind is intended.

analyzed: vibhu dvaya saṃyogasya tārkikaiḥ anupagamāt

analyzed: jñāna ayaugapadyāt ca tasya aṇu tvam matam

translated: This is an example of the occasional deviation of what is seen to co-occur in many cases.

analyzed: atha nidarśanam anyat pradarśayati katham ca iti

analyzed: aniyata adhiṣṭhāna iti

translated: In the case of the effect of fire, which has the quality of greatness, both color and touch are manifest, as in a flame.
